author: ahamlat
content: <@360491619402776577> related to EIP-8037, does the new  gas metering suggests that there is no limit in size (gas) for state creation transactions as EIP-7825 won't apply for them ?

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: The limit for the state is set by the gas limit (we allow transactions to go beyond the 16M again, but only at max 16M will go towards compute)

author: ahamlat
content: So for example, with 180 mgas gas limit, we can have transactions up to ~160 mgas (state heavy), correct ? I feel that it is breaking the benefits of EIP-7825

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: Why? You can still only execute 16Mgas of compute, so even if in theory you can create 160mgas worth of state, you can't because you are limited by the 16m

author: ahamlat
content: I agree that there is 16 mgas on compute, but we still can have within this limit a much bigger transaction, maybe not 160 mgas, but one that is much bigger than 16 mgas. Also we don't have a defined (hard limit), only the 16 mgas on compute. Maybe I misunderstood something. (I'm thinking about it as a worst case scenario that may not happen in reality)

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: No you're right, but the bigger transaction can not make the block be executed any slower

author: ahamlat
content: We would have to execute it sequentially, whereas if  we have multiple transactions we can parallelize especially with BAL. Why state creation transactions are not capped ? What about having a cap based  on the dynamic cost of a contract creation.

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: Sure, we can do a cap on the state part as well. But you can still parallelize the transactions. State creation will also incur normal gas costs btw. SStore would cost 2300 normal gas and 20000 storage gas. The normal gas part pays for the execution while the storage gas pays only for the state growth

author: ahamlat
content: I think it still makes sens to cap state transaction just in the same way compute ones are capped, also to be sure, in a big block, there will be still possibilities to parallelize even for worst cases. I get that we can still parallelize even without capping, but with capping we can parallelize even more.
